Code Documentation¶

generator.py¶

This is the generator module of Copper. The generator uses a genetic algorithm to find set of performance curves that matches the user-specified equipment definitions.

class copper.generator.generator(equipment, method='best_match', pop_size=100, tol=0.005, max_gen=300, vars='', sFac=0.5, retain=0.2, random_select=0.1, mutate=0.95, bounds=6, 10, base_curves=[], random_seed=None, num_nearest_neighbors=10)[source]¶

Bases: object

scale_fitnesses(fitnesses, pop, scaling=True)[source]¶

Scale the fitness scores to prevent best performers from dragging the whole population to a local extremum.

Parameters

  • fitnesses (list()) – List of fitness for each set of curves

  • pop (list()) – List of sets of curves

  • scaling (boolean) – Specifies whether of not to linearly scale the fitnesses

Returns

List of tuples representing the fitness of a set of curves and the set of curves

Return type

list(tuple())

curves.py¶

This is the curves module of Copper. It handles all operations and manipulation related to curves, set of curves, and sets of curves.

Normalize curve around the reference data points.

Parameters

  • x_norm (float) – First independent variable normalization points.

  • y_norm (float) – Second independent variable normalization points.

  • data (DataFrame()) – DataFrame() object with the following columns: “X1”,”X1^2”,”X2”,”X2^2”,”X1*X2”, “Y”.

  • curve_types (list()) – List of curves types

export(path='./', fmt='idf', name='')[source]¶

Export curves to simulation engine input format.

Parameters

  • path (str) – Path and file name, do not include the extension, it will be added based on the simulation engine of the SetofCurves() object.

  • fmt (str) – Input format type, currently not used. TODO: json, idf, inp.

Returns

Success

Return type

boolean

plot(out_var=[], axes=[], norm=True, color='Black', alpha=0.3)[source]¶

Plot set of curves.

Parameters

  • out_var (list()) – List of the output variables to plot, e.g. eir-f-t, eir-f-plr, cap-f-t. Refer to JSON files structure for other output variables

  • axes (matplotlib.pyplot.axes) – Matplotlib pyplot axes

  • norm (boolean) – Normalize plot to reference values

  • color (str) – Set of curves color

  • alpha (float) – Transparency of the curves (0-1).

Returns

Plotting success

Return type

boolean

check_vars_in_dictionary(vars, target_attr)[source]¶

method to check that the vars specified by the user exists in target_attr :param vars: list -> vars to calculate weights with, as specified by the user :param target_attr: list -> target attributes :return not_in_dict: list -> list of vars not in target_attr

get_aggregated_set_of_curves(method='weighted-average', N=None, ranges={}, misc_attr={})[source]¶

Determine sets of curves based on aggregation.

Parameters

  • method (string) – Type of aggregation, currently supported: ‘average’ and ‘median.

  • ranges (dict) – Dictionary that defines the ranges of values for each independent variable used to calculate aggregated dependent variable values.

  • misc_attr (dict) – Dictionary that provides values for the aggregated set of curves.

Returns

Aggregated set of curves.

Return type

SetofCurves()

l2_norm(df, target_attr, weights, vars=['full_eff', 'ref_cap'])[source]¶
Parameters

  • df – df -> dataframe containing the attributes of different equipments for a givne equipment type

  • target_attr – dict -> contains the target attribute we want to find the closest match

  • weights – list/np.array -> 1D list of weights. must have the same dimensions as vars

  • vars – list -> list of str containing variable names we want to compute l2 norm with

Return Y

np.array -> l2 scores for all equiplemts/curves. same dimension as the size of df

nearest_neighbor_sort(target_attr=None, vars=['ref_cap', 'full_eff'], N=None)[source]¶

This method performs the weighted average and the nearest neighbor approach. :param target_attr: dict -> target attributes we want to match :param vars: list of str -> the variables we want to use to compute our l2 score. note COP will be added :param N: int -> indicates the number of nearest neighbors to consider. N=None for weighted-average :param df: pd.DataFrame -> dataframe with selected chiller names and the associated weightings :return best_idx: int -> index of set_of_curve that should be the closest fit

normalize_vars(df, target_attr=None, vars=['ref_cap', 'full_eff'], epsilon=1e-05, weights=None, N=None)[source]¶
Parameters

  • df – df -> input dataframe containing the variable inputs

  • target_attr – dict -> reference targets with respect to which l2 score needs to computed

  • vars – list -> list of str for variables we want to normalize

Param

weights: list -> weights associated with each variable in vars

Param

N: Number of nearest neighbors. should be none unless method = “NN-weighted-average”

Returns

df: df with added columns with normalized variables

Return target_attr

dict -> added normalized values of var in vars

Return best_curve_index

int -> corresponding to the best curve

softmax(x)[source]¶

softmax function :param x: float -> convert distances to scores/weights using softmax function

library.py¶

This is the library module of Copper. It contains functions used to parse the JSON library files used by Copper.

find_equipment(filters=[])[source]¶

Find equipment matching specified filter in the curve library.

Special filter characters:

  • ~! means “all except…”

  • ! means “do not include…”

  • ~ means “include…”

Parameters

filters (list(tuple())) – Filter represented by tuples (field, val)

Returns

Dictionary of field for each equipment matching specified filter

Return type

dict[str,dict[]]

chiller.py¶

This is the chiller module of Copper. The module handles all calculations and data manipulation related to chillers.

class copper.chiller.chiller(ref_cap, ref_cap_unit, full_eff, full_eff_unit, compressor_type, condenser_type, compressor_speed, part_eff=0, part_eff_unit='', part_eff_ref_std='ahri_550/590', part_eff_alt=0, part_eff_unit_alt='', part_eff_ref_std_alt='ahri_550/590', full_eff_alt=0, full_eff_unit_alt='', set_of_curves='', model='ect_lwt', sim_engine='energyplus', min_unloading=0.1, min_plr=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

calc_eff_ect(cap_f_t, eir_f_t, eir_f_plr, eir_ref, ect, lwt, load)[source]¶

Calculate chiller efficiency using the ECT-based model for a specific ECT and load value (percentage load).

Args:

cap_f_t (Curve): Capacity curve modifier as a function of temperature (LWT and ECT) eir_f_t (Curve): Energy Input Ratio curve modifier as a function of temperature (LWT and ECT) eir_f_plr (Curve): Energy Input Ratio curve modifier as a function of part load ratio eir_ref (Float): Reference EIR ect (Float): Entering condenser temperature in deg. C lwt (Float): Leaving water temperature in deg. C load (Float): Percentage load, as defined in AHRI 550/590

calc_rated_eff(eff_type, unit='kw/ton', output_report=False, alt=False)[source]¶

Calculate chiller efficiency.

Parameters

  • eff_type (str) – chiller performance indicator, currently supported full (full load rating) and part (part load rating)

  • unit (str) – Unit of the efficiency indicator

Returns

chiller performance indicator

Return type

float

cond_inlet_temp_residual(lct, args)[source]¶
generate_set_of_curves(method='best_match', pop_size=100, tol=0.0025, max_gen=300, vars='', sFac=0.5, retain=0.2, random_select=0.1, mutate=0.95, bounds=6, 10, base_curves=[], random_seed=None, verbose=False, export_path='', export_format='json', export_name='', num_nearest_neighbors=10)[source]¶

Generate a set of curves for a particular chiller() object.

Parameters

  • method (str) – Method used to generate the set of curves: - best_match uses curves that best match the chiller object description

  • pop_size (int) – Population size used by the genetic algorithm

  • tol (float) – Tolerance used by the genetic algorithm to determine if the proposed solution is acceptable The lower, the more stringent

  • max_gen (int) – Maximum number of generation

  • vars (list()) – List of variable to run the alorithm on

  • sFac (float) – Linear fitness normalization factor, the higher the more aggressive the normalization will be

  • retain (float) – Probability of retaining an individual in the next generation

  • random_select (float) – Probability of randomly selecting an individual to be part of the next generation

  • mutate (float) – Probability of an individual to be mutated in the next generation

  • bounds (tuple()) – Random modification bounds (TODO: add more details)

  • random_seed (int) – Integer that is used to inialize the random number generator, this should be used when identical results are needed from one run to another

Returns

Set of curves object generated by the genetic algorithm that matches the chiller() definition

Return type

SetofCurves()

helpers.py¶

This file contains sundries which are not specifically used when using Copper but can be useful for its development.
